title-group.article-title: High temperature matrix resins based on bispropargyl ethers – part 1
title-group.subtitle: Effect of copper salts on the thermal polymerisation of bispropargylether of bisphenol-A and the thermal stability of these polymers

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemistry, Kamaraj College of Engineering and Technology, K. Vellakulam Post, India
2Defence Materials and Stores Research and Development Establishment (DMSRDE), Kanpur, India
3Department of Polymer Technology, Kamaraj College of Engineering and Technology, K Vellakulam Post, India

author-notes.corresp: Chinnaswamy Thangavel Vijayakumar, Department of Polymer Technology, Kamaraj College of Engineering and Technology, S.P.G.C. Nagar, K. Vellakulam Post 625701, India. Email: ctvijay22@yahoo.com

abstract.p: The compound bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A (BPEBPA) is prepared using phase transfer catalyst. Different copper salts like cuprous chloride (CuCl), cupric chloride dihydrate (CuCl2.2H2O), copper sulphate pentahydrate (CuSO4.5H2O), basic copper carbonate (CuCO3.Cu(OH)2), cupric acetate monohydrate ((CH3COO)2Cu.H2O), and cupric oxide (CuO) are blended separately with BPEBPA (1%, w/w) and the curing characteristics of these materials are investigated using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The presence of copper salt in BPEBPA shifts the curing temperature to a lower temperature region. The materials are thermally cured and the structural characterisation and the thermal properties of these cross-linked materials are investigated using Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer and thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA). Of the different copper salts investigated, the presence of copper sulphate pentahydrate in BPEBPA increases the thermal stability of the cured BPEBPA. The thermal degradation products of thermally cured pure BPEBPA and copper salts containing BPEBPA are studied using TG-FTIR. The phenols, substituted phenols, carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), and alkenes are major volatiles evolved during the thermal degradation of these materials.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Thermosets generally have better mechanical, thermal, and chemical properties. They also have excellent electrical resistance and dimensional stability than thermoplastics. Thermosetting resins are reactive low-molecular-weight oligomers or high-molecular-weight polymers having reactive functional groups for cross-linking reactions. After the thermosetting process, these resins become infusible and insoluble materials due to the cross-linking reactions and are irreversible. Cross-linking is responsible for providing hardness, strength, brittleness, and better dimensional stability. The curing reaction should provide not only cross-linking but also additional rigid ring structures. This becomes the base concept for high-performance thermosets.

The properties of high-performance thermosets become significantly dependent on the type of reactive functional groups. The end capping groups such as epoxy, maleimide, cyanate ester, acetylene, nadiimide, and so on are used to prepare structurally diverse thermosets having different properties.1 Acetylene-terminated resins have excellent thermal and heat resistance, high service temperature, low moisture uptake, and high strength.2 Propargyl-terminated resins are yet another very attractive acetylene reactive group–terminated resins. The ease of synthesis in high yields and purity offers an excellent scope for these resins.3–6

Major advantages of propargyl-terminated resins are long shelf life, good thermal stability, low moisture absorption, excellent adhesion, low dielectric constant, and acceptable physicomechanical properties. The formation of void free materials without the application of high pressures is an additional advantage of propargyl-terminated resins.4,7,8 The polymeric product formed after curing of the aromatic propargyl ethers exhibits an unexpected substantial improvement in the flexural modulus and flexural strength, compared with other resins.5

Bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A (BPEBPA) on uncatalysed thermal polymerisation in bulk gives cross-linked bischromenes.9–11 In the presence of certain specific catalysts, the propargyl group can undergo polymerisation through cyclo termination of acetylene function.2,10,12 The addition of inorganic salts is a useful means to improve both the thermal and mechanical stability of a polymer system.13,14 The most preferred catalysts for this process are Cu or Zn salts.5 Addition of catalyst (CuCl, CuCl2, and (C2H5)2Ni) to propargylic compounds causes a decrease in the polymerisation onset temperature.9,15 Catalytic amount of such copper salts is efficient in modifying the thermal behaviour of the curing reaction. Previous investigations on aromatic propargyl ether5 indicate cuprous chloride as the preferred catalyst. Elsewhere, catalysed polymerisation of alkynes has been widely investigated.16–18

In this present investigation, catalytic amounts of various copper salts such as cuprous chloride (CuCl), cupric chloride dihydrate (CuCl2.2H2O), copper sulphate pentahydrate (CuSO4.5H2O), basic copper carbonate (CuCO3.Cu(OH)2), cupric acetate monohydrate ((CH3COO)2Cu.H2O), and cupric oxide (CuO) were added to BPEBPA. The thermal-curing behaviour of these materials and pure BPEBPA was investigated using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The pure BPEBPA and copper salts-blended BPEBPA materials were cured thermally. The thermal stabilities of these materials were investigated using TGA and the results are presented and discussed. Evolved gas analysis technique (TG-FTIR) was used to determine the products formed during the thermal degradation of materials and a probable degradation mechanism is provided.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Bisphenol-A, sodium hydroxide, isopropanol, tetra butyl ammonium bromide, copper (II) hydroxide carbonate, and copper (II) acetate monohydrate were obtained from E Merck India Ltd., Mumbai, India, and were used without any further purification. Propargyl chloride obtained from Grauer & Weil (India) Limited, Vapi, India, was distilled (Boiling point: 57°C) before use. Cuprous chloride, cupric chloride dihydrate and cupric oxide were purchased from Loba Chemie Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India. Copper sulphate pentahydrate was obtained from Reachem Laboratory chemicals Pvt. Ltd., Chennai, India.

sec.title: Preparation of bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A (BPEBPA)
sec.p: A mixture of 45.6 g (0.2 mol) of bisphenol-A, 200 mL of 20% aqueous sodium hydroxide and 3.22 g (0.01 mol) of terabutyl ammonium bromide were kept at room temperature. About 44.4 g (0.6 mol) of propargyl chloride was added over a period of 10 min to the above mixture with constant stirring and the resultant reaction mixture was stirred for 16 h. The resulting white crystals were filtered and washed twice with 200 mL of water and then with 50 mL of isopropanol. This results in a yield of 44 g (95%) of BPEBPA (Figure 1).The product was dried in a vacuum oven and the material melts at 81°C.

sec.title: Blending of copper salts with BPEBPA
sec.p: The dried BPEBPA and the copper salt (99:1, w/w) were taken in an agate mortar and the mixture was ground repeatedly to have effective mixing. The mixture was then dried in a vacuum oven and preserved for polymerisation. The following blends were made: 99% BPEBPA + 1% cuprous chloride (BC1), 99%BPEBPA + 1% cupric chloride dihydrate (BC2), 99% BPEBPA + 1% copper sulphate pentahydrate (BCS), 99% BPEBPA + 1% copper (II) hydroxide carbonate (BCC), 99% BPEBPA + 1% copper (II) acetate monohydrate (BCA), 99% BPEBPA + 1% cupric oxide (BCO).

sec.title: Thermal curing
sec.p: The pure BPEBPA and the blends of BPEBPA with copper oxide and copper (II) acetate monohydrate were taken in separate borosilicate glass test tubes and flushed with dry oxygen-free-nitrogen gas and polymerised at 240°C for 6 h. And all the other BPEBPA-copper salt mixtures were polymerised at 205°C for 6 h. After the polymerisation, the samples were allowed to cool to room temperature and then removed from the test tubes, ground to coarse powder, packed, and stored for further analysis.

sec.title: Characterisation
sec.p: The Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the materials were recorded in a Shimadzu-8400S infrared spectrophotometer using KBr pellet technique. The absorption bands in IR spectra were used to identify the functional groups in the materials investigated. The DSC curves for pure BPEBPA and its blends with various copper salts (2–3 mg) were recorded in a thermal analysis (TA) instruments DSC Q20. The materials were hermetically sealed in the aluminium pans and heated at a rate of 10°C min−1 in dry nitrogen (50 mL min−1) atmosphere. The TG curves for all the thermally cured materials were recorded in a TA instruments TG Q50 system using 10°C min−1 heating rate in nitrogen atmosphere. Generally, 2 to 3 mg of the sample was used with a balance purge of 40 mL min−1 and a sample purge of 60 mL min−1. The TG-FTIR data for the polyBPEBPA samples were acquired in TGA Q5000V3.10 Build 258 system using a heating rate of 10°C min−1 from ambient to 800°C. The analysis was performed using 3–4 mg of the sample with a balance purge of 10 mL min−1 and a sample purge of 25 mL min−1. High purity dry nitrogen was used as the carrier gas.

sec.title: FTIR studies
sec.p: The FTIR spectrum of BPEBPA shows characteristic absorptions for ≡C–H and C≡C at 3,263 and 2,121 cm−1, respectively, present in the propargyl group. The absence of –OH band of the precursor bisphenol A at 3500 cm−1 confirms the completion of the reaction. The peak at 1,504 cm−1 is attributed to the phenyl nucleus stretching of BPEBPA. The absorption band at 696 cm−1 is attributed to ≡C–H deformation and the strong peak at 1,018 cm−1 for the aralkyl ether (Ar–O–CH2–) group of BPEBPA.

The proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectrum of BPEBPA shows the following chemical shift δ (ppm) values: 1.64 (s, 6H, C(CH3)2), 2.51 (s, 2H, ≡CH), 4.66 (s, 4H, CH2), 6.86 (d, 4H, aromatic), 7.16 (d, 4H, aromatic), which confirmed the structure of BPEBPA.9,19 The FTIR spectra of the different copper salt-blended BPEBPA were similar to the FTIR spectrum of neat BPEBPA. Hence, the physical blending of the copper salts did not show any interaction with BPEBPA.

The FTIR spectra of the thermally cured pure BPEBPA and its copper salt blends are shown in Figure 2. Thermally cured BPEBPA shows the band at 1,500 cm−1 for the phenyl nucleus stretching. The appearance of new broad band at 3,410 cm−1 indicates the formation of phenol entities during the curing process and the appearance of band at 1,604 cm−1 indicates the propargyl group is converted into chromene structure and the disappearance of ≡C–H stretching band at 3,263 cm−1, C≡C stretching at 2,121 cm−1 and ≡C–H deformation at 696 cm−1 confirms the complete polymerisation of BPEBPA.19 The appearance of vibration bands at 1,110–1,172 cm−1 corresponding to the –O–CH2– group of cyclic ether confirms the formation of chromene ring during polymerisation. The appearance of a very weak absorption at 887 cm–1 is attributed to the aromatic out-of-plane bending vibrations of the tri-substituted benzene ring.

caption.p: The FTIR spectra of the thermally cured pure BPEBPA and its copper salt blends (1%, w/w).
FTIR: Fourier-transform infrared; BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A.

sec.p: Grenier et al.7 studied the reaction mechanism and kinetics of the formation of prepolymers with propargylic terminal residues using FTIR. They reported that the appearance of new band at 1,632 cm−1 is attributing to the vibration movement of the chromene ring and 1,490 cm−1 is attributed to the vibrations of the ortho- and para- substituted phenyl groups. The appearance of bands between 1,100 and 1,200 cm−1 corresponds to the cyclic ether group (–O–CH2–) and the band at 880 cm−1 is attributed to the C–H deformation of a tri-substituted benzene ring. Finally, they concluded that the polymerisation of BPEBPA proceeds through the formation of chromene ring having cyclic ether group. From these results, the authors suggest that the propargyl group is converted into chromene structure containing C=C bond and cross-linking reaction occurs via the cleavage of C=C bond.

There are no significant changes noted for the bands corresponding to the phenyl nucleus and alkyl group for the thermally cured BPEBPA copper salt blends (Figure 2). Variations are noted in the bands corresponding to the cyclic ether group (1,100–1,200 cm−1) for the entire thermally cured materials investigated except BCO. The above band is split into a group of vibration bands (1,018, 1,126, 1,172, and 1,234 cm−1) for the thermally cured BCS and BCC. The materials BC1, BC2, and BCA showed absorptions at 1,118, 1,172, and 1,226 cm−1. From the above observations, it is concluded that the copper salts affect the final structure of the thermally cured BPEBPA. The nature and the degree of influence depend on the copper salt that is blended to BPEBPA.

sec.title: DSC studies
sec.p: The DSC curves are recorded (Figure 3) to understand the melting and curing characteristics of BPEBPA and its blends with different copper salts such as CuCl, CuCl2.2H2O, CuSO4.5H2O, CuCO3.Cu(OH)2, (CH3COO)2Cu.H2O, and CuO. The parameters obtained from the DSC curves namely, melting temperature (Tm), enthalpy of fusion (ΔHf), onset (Ts), maximum (Tmax), end set (Te) temperature of curing and enthalpy of cure reaction (ΔHc) are tabulated in Table 1. The pure BPEBPA shows a sharp melting point at 81°C with an enthalpy of fusion of 123 J g−1 and curing starts at around 120°C above the melting point. Generally, propargyl monomers are characterised by a broad fabrication cure window of more than 100°C from its melting stage, which allows their easy processability.4 The present DSC studies of BPEBPA showed that the thermal curing of BPEBPA starts at 205°C and attains maximum at 280°C and ends at 332°C and the enthalpy of the curing process is 730 J g−1. The thermal curing process of bispropargylether has been studied by many investigators,4,19 and the reported melting point for BPEBPA was 82°C. The exotherm of its uncatalysed curing starts at around 200°C with a maximum at 275°C and ends at 325°C. There is no characteristic change that occurred in the melting point of the BPEBPA and its copper blends. In the FTIR results the authors mentioned that blending of different copper salts with BPEBPA is not affecting the IR absorption bands pertaining to BPEBPA, indicating negligible interaction in the blended materials. The change that was observed in the ΔHf values for the pure BPEBPA and the BPEBPA/Cu salt blends provided good evidence for the interactions set in between BPEBPA and copper salts during heating. Especially, BCS, BCC, and BCA are having low ΔHf values. The interaction differed with the nature of copper salts added into BPEBPA. Except BCO, all other copper salts affect the curing process of the BPEBPA. According to thermodynamics, the change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for the melting transition of a sample is zero as it is an equilibrium phenomenon. Hence, from the melting point (Tm) and the heat of fusion (ΔHf), it is possible to calculate the entropy change (ΔS) associated with the melting. The calculated ΔS values are presented in Table 1. From the values, it is possible to say that the copper sulphate pentahydrate blended with BPEBPA system is showing a minimum change in ΔS value, indicating more orderliness than the other systems investigated. From the DSC curves it is observed that the onset curing temperatures of BC1 and BC2 are shifted to lower temperatures of 164 and 179°C, respectively, which are considerably earlier than pure BPEBPA. The curing temperature of these blends ends at 325°C. Whereas the onset curing temperature of BCS, BCC, and BCA starts at 189, 186, and 205°C, respectively, and ends at around 335°C. From Figure 3, of all the copper salts investigated except the curve for copper oxide all other copper salts addition to BPEBPA show nearly three stages of curing and all of them overlap each other. It indicates that the presence of copper salts in the molten BPEBPA alters the nature of thermal curing mechanism of the BPEBPA and in the temperature region 265–280°C all the materials show exothermic reactions. Figure 4 provides detailed information about the possible isomerisation reactions of the propargyl group and rearrangements during the process of curing. Douglas et al.10 and Kolb et al.5 reported the existence of rearrangement of BPEBPA during curing, resulting in the formation of mono- and di-2H-1-benzopyran (also called as chromene) in an uncatalysed system. The rate of formation of isomers and the isomers undergoing rearrangements differ, leading to the resultant change in the rate of polymerisation process. The presence of copper salts is influencing both the rates of isomerisation and polymerisation. This is exemplified in the pattern of the DSC curves that were recorded. Thus, the presence of copper salts in the molten matrix of BPEBPA definitely alters the curing mechanism since the rate of isomerisation of BPEBPA and hence the rate of polymerisation or curing is dependent on the nature of the copper salt. Lucotte et al.15 studied 1, 2-bis (3-propargyloxyphenoxy) ethane blends with 1% of cupric chloride and cupric sulphate salts. They reported that the incorporation of 1% of cupric chloride and cupric sulphate significantly shifts the onset temperature to the lower region and concluded that the catalytic amount of such cupric salts were efficient to modify the thermal behaviour of the reaction. From the above results, the incorporation of various copper salts was highly efficient to modify the thermal behaviour of the reaction. The observed ΔHc value of BPEBPA seemed to be slightly modified for all of its blends but the parameter is reduced by the presence of BC2. In contradiction, the values of ΔHc increases in the BCS, BCC, and BCA systems. Whereas there is no characteristic change in endotherm and exotherm for BPEBPA blends with BCO. As to the expectations, the parameters obtained from the DSC studies reveal the influence shown by the presence of various copper salts in the BPEBPA. From the results obtained, the incorporation of copper salts in BPEBPA will help in the processing of BPEBPA at a slightly lower temperature than pure BPEBPA.

caption.p: Various possible isomers and rearrangement products of BPEBPA during heating and its cross-linked network structure. BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A.
DSC curves for pure BPEBPA and its blends with different copper salts (1%, w/w).
BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; DSC: differential scanning calorimetric.
DSC Studies: melting and curing characteristics of BPEBPA and its blends with different copper salts (1%, w/w).

fn.p: BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; DSC: differential scanning calorimetric; CuCl: cuprous chloride; CuCl2.2H2O: cupric chloride dehydrate; CuSO4.5H2O: copper sulphate pentahydrate; CuCO3.Cu(OH)2: basic copper carbonate; (CH3COO)2Cu.H2O: cupric acetate monohydrate; CuO: cupric oxide.

sec.title: TG and DTG studies
sec.p: Thermogravimetric analysis is one of the commonly used techniques for rapid evaluations of the thermal stability of different materials and also indicates the decomposition of polymers at various temperatures. The TG and DTG curves for thermally cured BPEBPA and the copper salt blended BPEBPA are shown in Figures 5 and 6, respectively. The parameters obtained from the traces of TG and DTG namely onset of degradation (Ts), maximum (Tmax), and end set (Te) of degradation and char residues (%) at 750°C are tabulated in Table 2. The degradation temperature of thermally cured pure BPEBPA starts at 290°C, attains maximum at 441°C and ends at 590°C. The char residue for the BPEBPA noted at 750°C is 43%. For the thermally cured BC1, BC2, and BCA systems, the onset of degradation decreased to nearly 200°C that is 90°C earlier than polyBPEBPA and Tmax decreased to approximately 30°C earlier than pure BPEBPA. Degradation is over at approximately 40°C earlier than BPEBPA. These results show that the thermal stability of the materials decreases in the presence of the copper salt and the level of copper salts dispersion is also influencing the thermal degradation process. In the case of BCC, Ts is nearly similar to pure BPEBPA, attains maximum 30°C earlier and degradation over 60°C later than thermally cured BPEBPA. In the above cases, blending of copper salts with BPEBPA certainly enhances the degradation of thermally cured BPEBPA and it may be due to the diffusion of salts into the polymer matrix. The different levels of isomerisation and polymerisation of BPEBPA associated with the nature of the copper salt blended to BPEBPA as evidenced by the DSC studies (Figure 3 and Table 1) prove the possible variation in the final architecture of the thermoset produced. The diffusion of these salts into the polymer matrix is also a cause for the enhanced polymer degradation.20–22 Allara et al.20 studied the catalysis–inhibition effects of oxidised copper surfaces in the auto-oxidation of hexadecane. They reported that copper carboxylate salts, which were the catalysts for the oxidative degradation of the polyethylene, were formed at the polyethylene/copper interface. In the case of BCS, shift of Ts to higher temperature region is noted (320°C), Tmax is decreased nearly 30°C and degradation is over at around 80°C later than pure BPEBPA. From this, it is evident that the interaction existing between the network structures of the thermally cured BPEBPA and CuSO4.5H2O accelerated the degradation process in the initial stage. The propargyl group can undergo reaction through cyclo termination of the acetylene function in the presence of certain catalysts.10 As propargylation increases, the cross-linking density increases and should result in enhanced thermal stability. The incorporation of BPEBPA with BCO does not have any impact on thermal degradation (Table 2). The acceleration of the degradation of polymers in the presence of copper salts has been studied by many investigators.20,23 Hong et al.24 studied the effect of copper oxides on the thermal degradation of bismaleimide triazine (BT). They reported that the degradation temperature starts at 242, 236 and 237°C for the blank BT, BT with CuO and BT with Cu2O, respectively. Similarly, degradation attains maximum at 309, 301 and 300°C for bulk BT, BT with CuO and BT with Cu2O, respectively. BT resin with the copper oxide degrades earlier and easier than the pure bismaleimide triazine. Finally, they concluded that the selective adsorption of constituents on the metallic surface and the chemical reaction of polymer with the metal oxide (or) hydroxide could result in different degradation mechanisms in the polymer boundary zone. The above results confirm the effect of copper salts on the degradation reactions. The relative peak magnitudes and the peak shapes obtained in the TG thermograms indicate that the presence of Cu salts could change the degradation mechanisms of the pure BPEBPA. So, the blended copper salt in BPEBPA not only affects the degradation process but also alters the degradation mechanism of poly BPEBPA.

caption.p: DTG curves for thermally cured BPEBPA and BPEBPA blended with various copper salts (1%, w/w).
BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; DTG: differential thermogravimetric.
TG curves of thermally cured BPEBPA and BPEBPA blended with various copper salts (1%, w/w).
BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; TG: thermogravimetric.
TG and DTG studies: the degradation parameter for the thermally cured BPEBPA and BPEBPA blended with various copper salts (1%, w/w).

fn.p: BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; TG: thermogravimetric; DTG: differential thermogravimetric; CuCl: cuprous chloride; CuCl2.2H2O: cupric chloride dehydrate; CuSO4.5H2O: copper sulphate pentahydrate; CuCO3.Cu(OH)2: basic copper carbonate; (CH3COO)2Cu.H2O: cupric acetate monohydrate; CuO: cupric oxide.

sec.title: TG-FTIR studies
sec.p: TG-FTIR technique is a well-established and successfully applied method in the thermal analysis of organic or inorganic compounds. The application of this simultaneous technique allows the identification of the composition of gaseous products formed during degradation and the exploration of degradation mechanism. TG-FTIR technique was employed to examine the thermal stability of polyBPEBPA and its thermal degradation products. The TG-FTIR spectra of the degradation products obtained at various temperatures for polyBPEBPA are shown in Figure 7 and temperature regions are tabulated in Table 3.

caption.p: TG-FTIR studies: thermally cured pure BPEBPA and BPEBPA blended with various copper salts (1%, w/w).

fn.p: BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; CuCl: cuprous chloride; CuCl2.2H2O: cupric chloride dehydrate; CuSO4.5H2O: copper sulphate pentahydrate; CuCO3.Cu(OH)2: basic copper carbonate; ; TG-FTIR: thermogravimetric Fourier-transform infrared.

caption.p: TG-FTIR curves for thermally cured BPEBPA.
BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; TG-FTIR: thermogravimetric Fourier-transform infrared.

sec.p: The release of carbon dioxide (CO2) and carbon monoxide (CO) from the degrading polyBPEBPA was confirmed by the increase in the peak at 2,350 cm−1 (C–O stretching), and the evolution of gases of CO2 and CO was observed in the temperature region 250–800°C. The release of aromatic phenols from the polyBPEBPA in the temperature region 380–800°C is confirmed by the increase in the –OH stretching frequency (3,600 cm−1) and the maximum release of phenolic compounds is observed in the temperature region 380–550°C. The possibility of the presence of free phenolic groups in the thermally cured BPEBPA is minimum. Vinayagamoorty et al.19 studied the degradation of polyBPEBPA by off-line pyrolysis GC-MS technique and reported the formation of phenols and various substituted phenols. This can be explained due to the competitive C–C and C–O scissions of the chromene ring systems formed through the Claisen rearrangement of the aryl propargyl ether present in BPEBPA. The appearance peaks at 1,100–1,200 cm−1 is attributed to the release of ether group (–O–CH2) bearing volatiles. The release of ether products is noted in the temperature region 380–620°C. The appearance of peaks at 1,500 cm−1 and 3,010 cm−1 indicates the evolution of compounds having the alkenes group (C=C) and aliphatic hydrocarbon (–CH), respectively. The release of such degradation products is observed in the temperature region 380–620°C. From the above results, one can conclude that the obtained gaseous degradation products should be able to liberate by a cleavage at activated benzylic (or) propargylic site.

The possible isomerisation and the probable structural entity of the cured network of poly BPEBPA are illustrated in Figure 4. The possibility of isomerisation of the propargyl group to allene units followed by polymerisation is already presented.25 Annakutty et al.26 studied the pyrolysis of bisphenol-A and elucidated the mechanism of formation of phenols and substituted phenols from the degradation of bisphenol-A. Bogentoft et al.27 reported that the aryl propargyl ether contains two principal centers where the charge may be localised. Electron with drawing groups facilitates the localisation on the aromatic favouring loss of the substituent and formation of chromene ion. On the other hand, electron donating groups in ortho and para positions favour the ether oxygen as a site of the charge, which triggers the ether cleavage. Based on the above concept, it is easy to explain the liberation of phenols, substituted phenols, ethers, CO2, and CO from polyBPEBPA.

The TG-FTIR spectra of thermally cured pure BPEBPA and various copper salts blended BPEBPA (Figure 8) are similar, indicating similar degradation products that are evolving during thermal degradation but the temperature regions at which these products are evolved (Table 3) and the amounts of these products that are liberated are different as shown by the intensity of absorption. This hints that the final network structure formed from blending the copper salts with BPEBPA is definitely different from the structure of pure polyBPEBPA. For all the materials investigated, the evolution of CO2 and CO follows the same trend except for the sample BC1. Here the intensity of released CO2 and CO gradually increases then decreases and then increases. The peak pertaining to the ether product (–O–CH2) obtained from the degradation of propargyl ethers is overlapping with the peak particular for the compounds having C=C units in the materials BC1, BC2, and BCO. The release of these products from BCS, BCC, and BCA is distinctly seen in the temperature region at 350–580°C. It indicates the difference in the architecture of the network structure formed due to the influence of the added copper salt. From Figure 8 it is clear that the thermal properties can be tailored based on the type of copper salt added to BPEBPA. Thus, the incorporation of copper salts in BPEBPA affects the structure of the molten material and hence influences both the rate of isomerisation and the polymerisation of BPEBPA which is reflected in the final thermal stability of the cured BPEBPA.

caption.p: TG-FTIR curves for thermally cured various copper salt blended BPEBPA (1%, w/w). BPEBPA: bispropargyl ether of bisphenol-A; TG-FTIR: thermogravimetric Fourier-transform infrared.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: From bisphenol-A and propargyl chloride, the bispropargyl ether of bisphenol (BPEBPA) was prepared. Different copper salts (1%) were incorporated into BPEBPA and thermally cured. The conversion of propargyl group into chromene was confirmed by FTIR studies. The DSC studies showed that the presence of copper salts alters the exotherm cure. This helps in processing the BPEBPA marginally at lower temperature than that of pure BPEBPA. The rate of formation of isomers and the isomers undergoing rearrangements differ leading to the resultant change in the rate of polymerisation process. The rates of isomerisation and polymerisation were influenced by the presence of copper salts in BPEBPA. The presence of copper salt in the cured BPEBPA alters the degradation as evidenced by the thermogravimetric studies. Among the different copper salts investigated, BCS increases the thermal stability and other salts decrease the thermal stability of the polymer. This leads to the BPEBPA/Cu interface resulting from the preferential adsorption of copper surface that can cause different degradation behaviour from the pure BPEBPA. TG-FTIR studies of cured BPEBPA showed the evolution of phenols, substituted phenols, ethers, CO2, and CO from polyBPEBPA. The thermally cured BPEBPA with various copper salts blended liberates similar products but the intensity of released products is varied. The results prove that the final structure of cured pure BPEBPA and cured BPEBPA with copper salts is different. As thermosets obtained bispropargyl ether is hydrophophic, they are finding applications in the areas like coatings, adhesives, microelectronics, and fibre-reinforced polymer composite structures for aerospace applications.

ack.p: The authors express their sincere thanks to the Management and Principal of Kamaraj College of Engineering and Technology, S.P.G.C. Nagar, K. Vellakulam Post, India, for providing all the facilities to do the work.
